section.title: Generator
section.para: A 230VAC 12kVA 1500rpm diesel generator is available to provide 230VAC electrical energy when the vessel is off-grid or when the ship's batteries are depleted.

section.title: Generator controls
section.para: The generator control panel is located at the helm and offers three primary buttons:

listitem.para: Press to initiate the generator start sequence. The control panel will prepare the generator for starting and make up to three cranking attempts. If cranking is unsuccessful, check the control panel display for diagnostic information and consult the control panel manual for further instructions.
Press to stop the generator or cancel auto-start mode.
Press to place the generator in auto-start mode. In auto-start mode control of the generator is referred to the ship's domestic panel.
The domestic panel has two switches labelled GENERATOR:
In the on position causes the generator to start. The generator will continue running until the switch is turned off or the generator control panel is taken out of auto-start mode.

In the on position refers generator start control the the ship's battery management system controller. The battery manager will start the generator automatically to recharge the ship's batteries should they become severely depleted.

section.title: Generator electrics
section.para: The generator operates at 12VDC. A single 120Ah 12VDC cranking battery is installed on the port side of the engine room with an adjacent battery isolator switch and a dedicated 24VDC battery charger which is energised only when the ship is connected to shore or generator supply.

section.title: Generator exhaust
section.para: The generator has a dry exhaust system routed through a silencer and discharging through the transom.

section.title: Generator cooling
section.para: The generator engine is indirectly cooled through an immersed heat exchanger located in a protected cavity at the port side of the hull. The heat exchanger can be serviced from the engine room without the need for lift-out or dry-docking.
A subsidiary primary cooling circuit is used to heat the ship's thermal buffer through a heat transfer coil.
The primary cooling circuit is pumped by a mechanically driven engine mounted impeller.
The generator cabinet is actively cooled by a powerful fan which draws air from the engine room, through the cabinet and discharges through an insulated pipe at the transom.
